Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing an application received from Miss Mary B. Connors for the Kingsclear Indian Day School.

This girl has had 4 years experience and the Trustees at Newmarket speak very highly of her.

Reverend Father Harris recommends Miss Connors, and said that Inspector Anderson considers her an excellent teacher.

This is the only application that has been received to date and as teachers are very scarce and in great demand, I am forwarding this application for your early consideration.

Your obedient Servant,

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
May 8, 1942.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Kingsclear Indian Day School,
New Brunswick West Indian Agency,
Electoral District of York-Sunbury.

I desire to refer you to my memorandum of November 13, 1941, and Mr. Pratt's reply of December 1, 1941, approving the temporary appointment of Mrs. Lloyd Edwards as teacher of the above school for the balance of the academic year which ends on June 30, 1942.

We have a letter from Indian Agent Whalen recommending the appointment of Miss Mary B. Connors of Harvey Station, N.B., for the academic year 1942-43. Miss Connors has had four years' experience and the local School Inspector reports very favourably on her work. Rev. Father Harris, the local Parish Priest, also recommends her appointment.

Present prospects are that teachers will be difficult to secure for the coming academic year and I should appreciate it if you would advise me as soon as possible if Miss Connors' appointment can be approved.

Director.

PP
Minister's Office

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, May 16, 1942.

Deputy Minister

Re - Kingsclear Indian Day School,
New Brunswick West Indian Agency.

Referring to Dr. McGill's memorandum of the 9th instant, so far as this office is concerned, it will be satisfactory to appoint Miss Mary B. Connors, Harvey Station, N.B., as teacher at the above school.

W.J.F. Pratt,
Private Secretary.

Dr. McGill -

To note.
Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the instant, the Department approves the appointment of Miss Mary B. Connors as teacher of the Kingsclear Indian Day School for the academic year 1942-43. Arrangements should be made for her to re-open the school on October 1, 1942. She will be allowed salary at the rate of $150 per month plus bonus. I enclose the necessary forms which she should complete and return.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hosie
Supt. of Welfare

Mr. E.J. Whalen,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N.B.
Ottawa,
May 20, 1942.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Kingsclear Indian Day School
No. 286

In my memorandum of December 4, 1941, I advised you of the appointment of Mrs. Lloyd Edwards as teacher of the above-mentioned school. Her services will terminate July 1, 1942.

GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS AS TO THE USE OF FORM N.D.T. 1

To be accorded married, householder, widow or widower status, or to be allowed any tax credit in respect of dependents, an employee must complete and file Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate with his employer.

Subject to certain exceptions, for each employee, the employer is to forward one copy thereof to the Inspector of Income Tax for his district at the time of making his first remittance for National Defence Tax. The other copy of Form N.D.T.1 is to be retained on file by the employer until the end of the year.

In case where Form N.D.T.1 is not completed and filed, the employee is to be regarded for tax purposes as a single person without dependents.

It will accordingly be apparent that it is unnecessary for single persons without dependents to complete and file Form N.D.T.1.

When an employee becomes married, widowed, divorced or separated from his spouse or a status of dependents, is engaged to another employee during the year it will be necessary for such employee to complete and file Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate with each employer.

Form N.D.T.1 in duplicate should be sent to local banks, post offices, insurance companies, etc., for mailing to the Inspector of Income Tax.

SECTION 91 OF THE INCOME WAR TAX ACT

(Being Section 72 of C. G. Amended by Sec. 8 of Ch. 34, 1940 (Second Session) as Chap. 18, 1941.)

NOTE.—Section 91, as Parliament to have come into operation on July 1st, 1940, was repealed by the Act of July 1st, 1941; however, that the rate of National Defence Tax imposed by the Act mentioned, is included in Section 91.

To Whom Applicable

(1) In addition to the tax imposed by this Act, there shall be levied and paid upon the income of every person described in paragraphs (a) to (e), both inclusive, of subsection nine of this Act a tax to be known as the National Defence Tax at the rate:

Tax Rates

(a) in the case of a married person whose spouse is resident in Canada or any part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year; and in the case of a husband or wife where each have an income in excess of $600 per year;

(b) in the case of a single person, or of a widow or widower, whose residence is in Canada or any other part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year; or of seven per centum if the income exceeds $600 per year;

(c) in the case of a widow or widower with a son or daughter resident in Canada or any other part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada under twenty-one years of age who is wholly dependent upon such parent for support, or with a son or daughter under twenty-one years of age who is physically or mentally infirm, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(d) in the case of an individual who maintains a self-contained domestic establishment, or who is wholly dependent upon another individual dependent upon him and connected with him by blood relationship, marriage or adoption, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(e) in the case of a minister or clergyman in charge of a diocese, congregation or parish, or of a missionary sent to work among the Indians and Eskimos, a self-contained domestic establishment, and who employs therein on full time a housekeeper or servant, of five per centum if the income exceeds $1,200 per year;

(f) in the case of income taxable as provided by subsections two and four of section eleven of this Act, of seven per centum;

Proviso

Provided that they shall be allowed a tax credit of four dollars for the year 1940, fourteen dollars for the year 1941, and twenty-three dollars for the year 1942, for each of the following persons residing in Canada or any other part of the territory of the British Commonwealth of Nations or in a country contiguous to Canada and wholly dependent upon the taxpayer:

(i) a child, grandchild, brother or sister of the taxpayer under the age of twenty-one years or over twenty-one years of age and over wholly dependent on account of mental or physical infirmity;

(ii) a parent or grandparent of a taxpayer wholly dependent on account of mental or physical infirmity;

(iii) a child maintained by the taxpayer in Canada under a co-operative scheme sponsored by the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development of Canada or any of the provinces of Canada for children brought from the United Kingdom under a Government plan.

Except otherwise provided herein, none of the persons entitled to have the tax calculated as provided in paragraphs (c) or (d) of this subsection.

The Not to Reduce Basic Income

(2) If the tax assigned under subsection nine of this section shall cause the income of a single person or a husband or wife to be reduced below the amount of $600, or in the case of those persons referred to in paragraphs (b), (c) and (e) of subsection nine of this section, the husband or wife where each have an income in excess of $600 below $1,200, then to the extent that it would so reduce the income of the taxpayer such tax shall not be payable.

Extra

(3) Taxes imposed by this section, which have not been deducted at the source, shall be increased by the following amounts, which shall be imposed and collected with the tax:

If the tax is $25.00 but not more than $100.00, by $1.00.

If the tax is more than $100.00, by three per centum of the tax payable.

Persons Not Liable

Income of the following persons shall not be liable to tax under this Act:

(a) incorporated companies;

(b) persons and corporations mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (i), both inclusive, and in paragraphs (f) and (g) of section four of this Act;

(c) municipalities or municipal or public bodies which in the opinion of the Minister provide for funds of Government;

(d) the services paid and allowances of—

(i) warrant officers, non-commissioned officers and men of the Canadian Army, Military Police and Navy who serve in the Canadian active service forces, and

(ii) commissioned officers of the said forces while on active service beyond Canada or on active service in Canada whose duties are of such a character as are required normally to be performed abroad or in aircraft.

Deduction by Employer

Every employer at the time of payment of earnings to an employee shall deduct and collect the tax imposed on the employee under this section and pay the same to the Receiver General of Canada. Five thousand nine hundred and forty-one dollars shall be remitted to the Receiver General of Canada on or before the first day of July, one thousand nine hundred and forty-one.

Remittance by Corporation

Each incorporated company referred to in subsection seven hereof shall remit the amounts collected to the Receiver General of Canada, on or before the fifteenth day of the month immediately following the date of payment of the interest or dividends, the first remittance to be made on the sixteenth day of September, 1940.

Returns

Every person required to make deductions under this section shall make a return at such time and in such form as the Minister may prescribe showing all deductions.

Persons Deemed Trustees

Every person deducting any amount under this Act shall be deemed to hold the same in trust for the Receiver General of Canada.

Legal Immunity

No one shall have any right of action against an employer or incorporated company in respect of amounts deducted as a tax and paid over to the Receiver General of Canada in compliance with or intended compliance with this section.

Forms and Returns Required

Every employee who comes within one of the classes described in paragraphs (a), (c) and (d) of subsection nine of this section shall be required to complete such form as the Minister may prescribe as to personal status and dependants and shall file the form with his employer.

Provided that a like form shall be so filed in each case where the facts as given in the form are changed by absence, return or by a change in the number of dependents.

Tax Not Fully Paid by Deduction

Every person liable to taxation under this section whose tax hereunder has not been fully paid by deduction at the source, shall, on or before the thirty-first day of March in each year without written notice or demand, file with the Minister the prescribed form in the Minister's prescribed form of his total income during the last preceding year and shall pay any tax due at such times and in such manner as in this Act provided.

Offences and Penalties

Every person failing to deduct, remit or to deduct and remit the tax due pursuant to the provisions of this section at the time prescribed therefor shall be liable to a penalty equal to the amount of tax which should have been deducted and remitted, and the penalty shall not exceed five hundred dollars.

Failure to File Form

Every employee failing to file the prescribed form with his employer pursuant to the provisions of subsection twelve hereof shall have the tax deducted at the source at the rate of five per centum of the tax payable and shall be charged the tax credit to which he would otherwise have been entitled in respect of persons dependent upon him for support.

"Employee"

"Employer"

"Employee" shall for the purposes of this section include any person who receives as income any salary, wages, remuneration, compensation, hire, emolument, stipend, perquisite, or any similar payment or any indemnity, pension or director's fee, howsoever paid for any services, functions or duties rendered or performed in Canada.

"Employer"

"Employer" shall for the purposes of this section include any person who makes any payment of the descriptions referred to in subsection sixteen of this section.

Records to be Kept

Every person required to deduct the tax hereby imposed from any payment made to him, shall keep a record of all persons to whom any such payments are made, showing their names, residential addresses, the dates and the amounts of such payments and such other information as the Minister may require.

Refunds

The Minister may make refund to the taxpayer of any amount collected under this section which was not exigible or which the Minister is reasonably satisfied was not exigible under this section, provided the taxpayer applies in writing for such refund within six months from the close of the calendar year in which the tax was collected.

Deductions

Income (except salary or other fixed payments referred to in subsection sixteen hereof) shall for the purposes of this section be subject to the deductions provided by paragraphs (a), (b), (f), (k), (l) and (o) of subsection one of section five and to the provisions of section six of this Act.

Exemptions

Income shall be taxed under this section without exceptions, deductions, allowances or credits, and without deductions of contributions by civil servants referred to in section twenty-four of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1935, chapter twenty-four of the Revised Statutes of Canada, 1935.

Time for Making Deductions

Ottawa,
April 22, 1944.

Mr. E.J. Whalen, Indian Agent, Fredericton, N.B.

On checking the March quarter return of the Kingsclear Indian Day School, it is noted that only four pupils were registered during that quarter. The same condition applied to the December quarter, but we were under the impression at that time that possibly owing to sickness and bad weather the attendance had been reduced. However, as there are still only four children registered at the school, it would appear that these are the only pupils available. In view of the great shortage of teachers at the present time, the Department does not feel that we are justified in operating a school for four pupils. However, it is not our intention to close the school immediately, but, unless you can give definite assurance that there will be a much larger attendance for the coming academic year, the Department will have no alternative than to close the school at the end of June. Please let me know why the attendance at this school has become so low and also what are the prospects of an increased attendance.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to refer to your letter of April 22, 1944 regarding the small number of pupils at the Kingsclear Indian Day School.

Since Ernest Polchies was sent to the School for the Blind at Halifax, there has been only four pupils.

The number of children in this reserve has been lessened some by Indian families moving away when the father obtained a good job at some kind of war work. This condition will last as long as the war lasts.

There is however a new side to this problem now. Henry Solomon, an Indian from Kingsclear reserve, who has been employed in Maine for some time, disappeared Christmas eve last year. Last week his body was found in the river near Presqueisle, Maine.

This man left five children and two of these have been given a home by relatives in Kingsclear Indian Reserve. Henry Barney Solomon, Age 12 taken by Benjamin Tomah. Reginald Solomon, Age 13, taken by Gabriel Solomon.

I did not know that these boys were coming to Kingsclear to live until after they arrived, but the relations had talked of taking the children when they heard of Mr Solomon's disappearance, if he did not show up. His wife, who turned out to be a bad woman, left the family some time before his disappearance. The Indians say she is now serving a term in a house of correction at Skowhegan, Maine.

This increases the number of children at school by two, or fifty per cent. Mrs Frank Sappier another woman of the Kingsclear reserve has been talking of adopting a child. If she does and it is of school age this will increase the number to seven pupils.
When the Indians were aware of the fact that the school might be closed on account of the small number of pupils, they began to ask for children to adopt. I did not know if this would meet with your approval or not, and so I did not say much about it.

Of course the ones who adopted the Solomon children had said when he was reported missing that if Mr Solomon did not return to the family they were going to adopt some of the children, therefore their action had nothing to do with the school problem.

The Indians of the Kingsclear reserve do not look kindly on the idea of closing their school and feel that they are being discriminated against as they say the war conditions have caused their men to go away and the children as well.

There are, as stated above, two more pupils to go to school now and if the school would be kept open by one more pupil being adopted by a family and kept at school I feel that we would have no trouble in placing one in a good home with Mr and Mrs Sappler, who have no children of their own.

Your further comments please.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Deptt. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Enclosed you will find resignation of Miss Mary B. Connors, teacher of the Kingsclear Indian Reserve.

Miss Connors has had several offers in graded schools at a better salary than she has been receiving from us.

I am trying hard to find another teacher but so far I have not been able to find one not already hired. If I can get an application from a teacher in the near future I will forward it immediately.

Edward J. Whalen
Indian Agent.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON N.B. SOUTHWESTERN AGENCY

Four schools, one on each reserve, are being conducted for the education of the children. Two of these schools, the Woodstock and the Saint Mary's are looked after by two teachers, each, Sisters of Charity, and in addition to the regular work sewing, knitting, repairing of old clothing, cooking and weaving are being taught. The Kingsclear and Oromocto Schools each have but one teacher consequently very little time can be spent on Domestic Science work.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Each reserve in this agency has an Indian school. Two of these schools, Woodstock and Saint Mary's are taught by Sisters of Charity. Two Sisters in each school. The other schools, Kingsclear and Oromocto, have one teacher each.

The Woodstock school and the Saint Mary's school are each too small to accommodate the number of pupils and these should be replaced by new ones.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 12, 1945.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.

the Indian day schools in New Brunswick. I find that
there were no children in attendance at the Kingsclear

January 16, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your letter of December 12, 1945, inquiring about the number of pupils at the Kingsclear Indian Day School, has been received and would have been answered before, had not the Indians informed me that two families, formerly of this reserve were to return during the Christmas season.

At the present time, the total number of children of school age is only four.

Gregory Francis, an Indian of this reserve is in the Canadian Armed Forces, overseas, but is expected home at any time. His wife is a girl from the Woodstock Indian Reserve and during his absence, she moved to Woodstock with her people. On their return, which may be at any time (as soon as the husband returns) there will be one more pupil to attend school and next year they will have a second one of school age.

David Solomon, another Indian of this reserve has been working in a war plant in Connecticut, U.S.A., he was to have returned at Christmas, but has not, as yet. He has two small children to attend school.

Frank Sappier, has an adopted child, which will be of school age in another year.

If the building program on the Kingsclear

(over)
Reserve, which was talked of recently, materializes, then, the school will be too small to accommodate the pupils.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to refer to your letters of January 23 and May 18, 1946, regarding the attendance at the Kingsclear Indian Day School.

There are at the present time six children in attendance at this school.

There are three others, who have passed their fifth birthday and although they are too young to start at the beginning of the school year, they will be in attendance during the second term.

The matter of closing the school came up about a year ago and at that time the Indians of the Kingsclear Reserve, felt they were being deprived of a great deal, which other reserves had.

I would recommend, if at all possible, that this school be kept open, as I expect an increase in the number of pupils yearly.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N.B.

We are in receipt of a report from School Inspector Titus with reference to his inspection of Kingsclear School on February 17th. He states that there are seven children enrolled but only two of them were present on the day of the inspection. He further advises that there are five pupils in Grade I and of these, four are only five years of age.

The Inspector feels that these children are too young to attend school and he expressed the opinion that the teacher is very handicapped by the fact that they do not understand English.

From the information contained in your letter of June 17th, 1946, the Department was hopeful that the attendance would increase. However, it appears to be decreasing. Certainly, neither the enrolment or the attendance is such as to justify the continued operation of this school.

As you were informed in official letter of June 21st, 1946, we are prepared to allow the school to remain open for the current academic year but as things stand at the present time, there appears to be very little hope of reopening it next year. Is there any white school in the immediate neighbourhood of the Kingsclear Reserve that the Indian children of school age could attend?

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, March 11th, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Kingsclear Indian School.

With the proposed enlargement of the Kingsclear Indian Reserve, and the desire to have all the Indians of the Oromocto Reserve moved there during the coming season, it will be necessary to make plans for the school during the fall term, as it is expected that between 30 and 40 pupils will be there to attend school during 1947 and 1948.

As the Sisters have had such marked success in the Indian schools of the maritime provinces, and especially in the Domestic Science and welfare work, I would recommend, that, if at all possible, Sisters be employed to take charge of this school during the coming year.

They could be housed for the present time, in the house on the C. C. Murray property, recently purchased.

I have not approached the Mother Superior in St. John, regarding the Sisters to take over this work, as I wished to hear from you regarding same before approaching her. But, I feel, as there is a resident Priest and a Church at Kingsclear, we would be able to get the Sisters.

Mrs. Hurley, at present teaching the Kingsclear School, has informed me, it is her intention to resign at the end of the present term, and Miss Delaney, who is now employed as teacher, at the Oromocto Indian School could, in all probability, be placed elsewhere to good advantage.

May I hear from you regarding the employment of two Sisters at the Kingsclear Indian School.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, April 28th, 1947.

Dear Sir:

We have received your application form for employment as a teacher in an Indian day school. We have vacancies for Roman Catholic teachers in the Province of British Columbia. In fact, we have one school to which you could report as a teacher on July 1st, 1947. Our beginning salary for teachers with first class certificates and no teaching experience is $126.00 a teaching month.

At the Okanagan Indian day school to which I referred in the opening paragraph of my letter, you will find good living quarters and furniture. The school has been closed for the past year and we are anxious to get a Catholic teacher as soon as possible. The school is situated seventeen miles from Vernon, B.C., and it will be necessary for you to do your own housekeeping.

There will be other vacancies occurring in the summer in Ontario and there may possibly be a vacancy in Nova Scotia.

Could you please inform me of what part of Canada you particularly want to be employed in.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

St. Francis Xavier College,
Antigonish, N.S.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent,

Kingsclear Indian Day School

Reference your Letter of April 19th.

We wish to advise that we do not employ two teachers at a school unless there is an average annual attendance of at least 30 to 35 during the academic year. You will agree that we could scarcely employ an additional teacher on the "expectation" indicated in your letter.

We understand from Mr. Morris that he has other plans for the house on the Murray property.

We have received an application for employment in Indian Schools from Mr. A.E. Hawley who holds a first class teaching license, physical education diploma and a Bachelor of Arts degree. Mr. Hawley is at present attending Saint Francis Xavier University at Antigonish.

On our new salary scale we can offer him a starting salary of $126. a teaching month.

From the above it should not be inferred that we do not wish to employ Sisters as teachers at this school. However, we are not prepared to employ two teachers at the present time.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Pedley,

The Department called for tenders for the erection of a school-house on the Kingsclear Indian Reserve, which were receivable at noon yesterday. Two tenders were received, one from Mr. Fred Jeffrey of Fredericton for the sum of $3590.00, accompanied by his cheque for 10 per cent of that amount not marked accepted by the Bank of Nova Scotia on which it is drawn; the other from Mr. Judson Barker of Fredericton for the sum of $3942.00. Mr. Barker has sent in an accepted cheque on the Bank of Nova Scotia for the required amount. Mr. Jeffrey's tender is the lower by $352.00 and if his cheque is marked good I would recommend the acceptance of his offer.

A building on the same plan was put up last year at St. Mary's last year at a cost of $3287.00, but Kingsclear is not so advantageously situated for getting in material.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the Thirty First day of October A.D. 1913.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

I beg leave to say I visited the new Indian School which is being built on the Kingsclear Reserve on the 3rd of September and my attention was called to the fact that there is no provision in the contract for draining the cellar.

Mr Jeffry the Contractor, Mr Goodwin the Inspector and myself are of the opinion that it would be safe to have a drain from the cellar although the building is on high ground there is a thick layer of clay about 18in from surface which prevents the water from soaking away and we are of the opinion it will soak through the wall and with a concrete below the water can not get out without a drain.

Dear Sir,

I am writing today to know whether or not we have to pass the remainder of this winter in the old school, where we have suffered with cold all the month of January. The school has not even been banked for the Agent told the man not to bother about it, and consequently the floor has been like ice and it was so hard to get it warm some days that we could not even open a window, so have been using cold storage air, which was not at all sanitary.

Now, the new building which has been ready since December, is, in the estimation of everyone whom I have heard speaking of it, almost perfect, of course with the exception of Mr. Smith, who I believe does not think it good enough for the Indians.

But I do think that it must be almost ruined by now by the frost.

Hoping to hear that we may soon have a move to where we can work & live comfortably. I remain Yours Truly [Signature]

Sir,

In submitting my inspection report of the Ringo Clan School, I would respectfully call your attention to the fact that while the new school at Hall Reserve seems ready for occupancy, the children are still obliged to use the old school house.

It is stated for your information that the old building has not been heated this winter, as it has been customary, and as the weather has been very cold. The building in question has been most uncomforatable, and trying on both teacher and pupils. I have been to this reserve a few times during the fall and recently and expected from day to day to see a change made to the old building. As this has not been done to date, I feel it is necessary to call your attention to the matter, in the interests of the children.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 1st instant, informing the Department of the price that would be charged per quart for supplying the milk required for use by the pupils in the four Indian day schools in your Agency.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the supplying of the following quantities of milk during each school day beginning November 2nd, next:

Woodstock Indian Day School - 4 quarts per school day
Kingsclear - 6 quarts per school day
St. Mary's - 6 quarts per school day
Grosseto - 6 quarts per school day

The cost of the milk, delivered, should not exceed the price mentioned in your letter, viz., 10 cents per quart.

The teacher should keep an accurate list of the milk supplied each day, and this list should be handed to you at the end of each month, when you should prepare a voucher, in duplicate, for the amount due and forward same to the Department, together with the list showing the quantity of milk delivered at each school. A separate account should be forwarded covering the cost of the milk supplied each school.

It is expected that the teachers will see that this milk is received in clean containers and that it is kept in a sanitary condition, also that the full quantity received is used by the pupils each day, without waste.

Our funds this year are limited, and it is considered that if this milk is supplied from the beginning of November, next, and continued until the end of April, next, the pupils would be provided with milk during the fall, winter and early spring months, and that there would not be the need of continuing the milk after the end of April, next. Please bear this in mind, and arrange that the milk be served the pupils between the period above mentioned - November 1st to April 30th, next.

Your obedient servant,

July 19th. 1932.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department, the school at Kingsclear Indian reserve is in a wretched condition, that is, the ceiling and the walls. I have a man working up there washing the ceilings and side walls. He is using washing soda and anything that will remove dirt, but this does not make a decent job, there are dark spots which cannot be washed off.

I would recommend the ceilings and walls be given one coat of paint. This would cost approximately seventy-five dollars, including work and material. This would give the interior of the school a bright and clean appearance, which would correspond with the other schools in my agency. I hope the Department will approve of this work, as it would be money well spent.

An immediate reply would be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs.

The interior of this school should, if possible, be painted. However, if funds are too low, the next best thing would be to have a proper person to wash walls and ceiling and woodwork with a proper chemical wash, that will remove the blackened condition of the interior.

The floor must be washed, well dried and covered with hot oil, the out-houses white-washed, cleaned and repaired and a little minor repairs about school steps and fence, etc.
Ottawa, June 17, 1933.

Sir:

Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, has forwarded the reports on his inspection of the schools in your Agency.

Regarding the Kingsclear Day School, he recommends that the interior woodwork be washed, and the floor scrubbed, and, when dry, given a coat of hot oil. You should arrange, during the summer holidays, to have the interior woodwork well washed and the floor scrubbed by a person competent to do the work.

He also recommends that the out houses at all the schools be thoroughly cleaned and placed in a satisfactory condition, and any minor repairs required carried out. The out houses at all the schools should be cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition. Indian labour should be employed as far as possible.

Accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the expenditure for each school separately.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge Department letter of June 17th, File 56-2-5, instructing me to have the school walls, ceiling's and woodwork washed and cleaned. Last year I had a man try and wash the walls at the Kingsclear Indian School. He had all the materials necessary to remove dirt, but the dust and smoke would not wash off. I would recommend the walls and ceiling of this school be painted, one or two coats. The cost would be very light, not more than fifty dollars, perhaps less, and would mean a great improvement to this school.

The school at Kingsclear is the only one in my Agency that the interior looks shabby. I would like very much to have this work done, so the interior of all all the schools would be clean and tidy.

Sir:

I beg to inform the Department there will have to be some work done at the Kingsclear Indian School. When the snow melts in the spring, or it rains, the water runs into the cellar and lies there, and this causes a musty odor in the school. There is a window on the north side of the school in the cellar wall, which could be closed by filling in with stone and cement. This would stop most of the water getting in. What really should be done, is a drain on the upper side of the school, to continue about ten rods; dig this drain a foot or two below the cellar floor, and fill with rock. This would carry the water away.

I would recommend the window be closed as referred to above. If the Department approves of this work being done, I will get an estimate of the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

File No. 56-2-5 regarding the furnace in the Kingsclear
Indian Day School.

The castings are all burned, or rusted out, the
fire box has several holes in it.

The furnace smokes so badly the ceilings and
walls are almost black. In the opinion of Mr. Betts, who
is a competent plumber not worth repairing. It will cost
approximately $10.00 to take the furnace down, and to
weld the holes which are visible, without taking it apart,
the cost $14.00, there will be another charge of $10.00
to reassemble it.

If the Department has not received any complaints
regarding this furnace it could not have been inspected
recently.

After a careful investigation, I beg to suggest
to the Department it would, in my opinion, wasting money
to spend much on repairs.

I therefore recommend the installation of a
new furnace, castings only, at an approximate cost of
$130.00.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

It is noted that in forwarding your voucher No. 411, in connection with supplies for destitute Indians, you included an item covering the cost of hardware supplied to the Kingsclear School.

I wish to point out that expenditure for Indian schools should not be included on any other voucher. When you are authorized to make an expenditure in connection with any of the schools in your Agency you should forward a separate voucher so that it can be attached to the file concerning that special school. This is the only manner in which the Department can keep a check on expenditures at each school. It is impossible to do so if school expenditure is included on other vouchers.

I feel certain that you will co-operate fully with us in this regard.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Reverend Father Harris and Chief William Pelchies went to the school on the Kingsclear Reserve to put a box of books in that Father Harris had taken to the reserve from the express office.

On entering the room they found things scattered all over the floor and every evidence that strangers had been in the school. The door was locked as usual but evidently it had been picked so I told the Chief to go to the Hardware store and get a lock that could not be picked.

E.M.Yeung Ltd. hadn't any locks and all that we could get at Neils was in the price class shown (unless of course we took cheap locks which were no good). It was more than I had planned on paying for a lock but under the circumstances there was no choice.

Edward J. Whalen,

November 26, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.
Re: Painting & Repairing of the Kingsclear Indian School and Outbuildings.

In my letter of July 4, 1945, I stated that I considered the cost of painting and repairing the Kingsclear Indian School and Outbuildings, including a well house would be $208.50. I now find that the cost of labor is about four times what I had figured on. More material too, was required which brought the cost still higher.

The extra labor and material was due to the condition of the school, which was much worse than could be seen until work was started on it. The metal ceiling, when cleared of the scale paint was rusty and had to be scraped and washed before being painted. Many holes had to be repaired in the walls and some of the window sashes were rotten and had to be replaced, others repaired. The building on the top of the roof was also in bad shape and had to be repaired. The flag pole too, had been placed on the top of the porch entrance and started the porch from the top main building. The pole itself, was also rotten and had to be taken down. In all, many unforeseen repairs were required. The outside walls of the building had to be scraped with a wire brush before being painted. Wages too, were higher than I had planned, help was scarce and there was no alternative.

(over)
only to take who I could get and to pay the same per hour as these people could get elsewhere.

Mr. William Polchies, an old reliable Indian, looked after the work, but, got very little help from the rest of the Indians, as they said they could make more money in Maine picking potatoes. I told this man to hire a white man to help him. Al Myshral was hired. (This man supplied many of the materials required for repairs to the school without charging for them).

It is regretted that my estimate was so much below the actual cost of the work. I visited this school often, as may be seen by my Daily Diary and tried to get the work hurried along, but as stated above, very much unforeseen work kept showing up and it was impossible to rush any.

On October 12, I told Mr. Polchies, that as the work had cost so much, we would have to close it out in two days more.

When J. E. Morris (Welfare Division), visited this school, I showed him the work and explained this. He authorized the completion of the work, which has been done.

A further advance of $271.22 will be required to finish the work as shown on the attached sheet, and I would ask that this be forwarded at an early date.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Furnace, Kingsclear Reserve.

The pipeless furnace in the Kingsclear Indian School, has been smoking during the past winter. I thought this was due to the worn out pipes, and I replaced these by good ones, although not new ones, which were obtained from the Internment Camp, Ripples, N. B. This, however, did not help matters much, and the stove continues to smoke.

The Indians claim this furnace has been in use at the Kingsclear Indian Reserve for about twenty-two years; therefore, I would ask to have authority to have it dismantled and repaired by a tinsmith, if repairs can be made without too much cost.

No estimate of the cost can be obtained, until the outside of the furnace is removed.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 3, 1947.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent,
Fredericton, New Brunswick.

Furnace - Kingsclear Indian Day School

The Department authorizes the dismantling and repair of the smokeless furnace at the above school. It is understood that this furnace is 22 years old and has been smoking during the past winter.

It is suggested that these repairs be carried out during the Easter holidays. If you find the furnace in bad condition it may be advisable to replace it entirely, but we will expect to hear further from you in this regard.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Fredericton, N. B.
January 5, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

It will be noted that the name of Donald Solomon, appears on the list of those who performed labour on the Kingsclear Indian School.

Consequently, the amount paid to this man included, as well as his own labour, $12.00 which he advanced to Donald Solomon and $2.00 which he paid for truckage.

Sir,

In view of the removal of all Indian families from Upper Elgin town, Queens County, N.B., to the Oromocto Reserve, I hasten to inform you that during my visit to Oromocto Reserve on the 27th inst., I find that at the present time there are twenty-five children between the age of five and fifteen years, that are attending the school, and are growing up in ignorance and without sufficient education. Some are in fact able of their children are bright and intelligent. In the past, I have done my best to get them to attend the Oromocto school, but owing to their previous habits, they will not keep up with white children. As the Department is deeply interested in the education of the rising generation, I feel that the time has arrived that a school building should be erected on this Reserve, and a teacher appointed for their special instruction.

Yours sincerely,

James Macmillan

OTTAWA, 19th October, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Farrell, in his letter of the 30th ultimo, urges the establishment of a day school at Oromocto stating that there are 25 children between the ages of six and fifteen years who are growing up in ignorance and attend no school. Their parents he states will not send them to the white school and if the Department decides to accede to this request, fully $700.00 would be required for the erection of a suitable building, with $100.00 extra for equipment, and $300.00 a year for the salary of a teacher. After all this expenditure had been gone to, it is doubtful whether they would take advantage of the school when established. I think it would be better to have the Agent use his influence with the Indians to have the children attend the white school even if the Department had to hold out inducements in the way of furnishing the necessary clothing for such children as could be persuaded to go there.

Ottawa, March 3, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ult., stating that the Indians of the Oromocto reserve have applied to you for the establishment of a school.

In reply I beg to say that a similar application was made some time ago through Mr. Agent Farrell, who was informed that the Department did not think it would be justified in incurring the expenditure necessary to build, equip and maintain a school on this reserve, owing to the unsettled habits of the Indians and more especially as there is a white school in the immediate neighborhood, where the Indians can, if anxious to have their children educated, send them.

The Department would willingly pay their tuition fees and furnish them with the necessary books and stationery and might even go so far as to assist them in providing articles of suitable wearing apparel.

The Department would be glad if you would visit

Rev. J.J. Ryan,
Superintendent of Indian Schools,
St. Mary's Ferry, N.B.
the reserve at your earliest convenience and use your best endeavors to persuade the Indians to avail themselves of the offer above referred to, and it considers that if the proposition is fairly laid before them they will accept it, if they are anxious to have their children educated.

Your obedient Servant,

Secretary.
Sir:

Referring to your communication No. 265-2791 under date of March 25th inst., I need say that I met the Indians at the reserve on their reserve Tuesday last and placed before them the views of the Department relative to the schooling of their children.

The majority of the Indians present were in favor of accepting the views of the Department to have their children attend the Village School until the Department might see its way clear by granting them a School of their own so that none...
I called on the school trustees to ascertain if some provision could be made in the Public School for the accommodation of the Indian children. Mr. Barnett, one of the trustees informed me that the school house was too small to take in any more children— that they had already refused applications from a side— that even supposing that the ratepayers would agree to this proposition they would certainly have to employ another teacher, as the present teacher had already too much to do.

I asked him to consult with the other trustee whom I did not see, and also to try and get the ratepayers to agree to taking the Indian children into their school at least for a year, and see how it worked out. This he promised to do, and will let me know the result early next spring.

As soon as I hear from him I will communicate the result.

As teacher of the Moncton Indian School, I have to ask for an increase of salary for this school year, the term beginning Aug. 24th.

The duties have been and will be, for an able, yet more trying than in a place where the children have been placed in the discipline of school life for years. I am sure the Inspector, Rev. Ryan and Commissioner Mr. White will assure you that I have endeavored to perform faithfully all duties in connection with this school, with quite gratifying results.

I desire also to call to your attention a little grievance in connection with my salary for the past year.

The salary was to have been three hundred dollars. I received two hundred and fifty, $25 for first quarter, and $75 for each succeeding quarter. During the school year I lost eight teaching days through owing to rooms being shut on the school building. For these days I did not expect pay.

You will readily understand it being no fault of mine that I was appointed teacher of this school first of August instead of first of July. And that the opening of the school was delayed for eight days.

Memorandum:

Schools Branch,

With respect to the attendance of school children as referred to in Mr. Agent Smith's letter hereunder, dated the 26th instant, I beg to point out that under Section 6 of the regulations relating to the Education of Indian Children, it is the duty of the truant officers to make every effort to see that the children attend school regularly and to arrest and convey to school any child not sick or otherwise lawfully excused from attending school that they may find absent from school during school hours.

I would, therefore, have the truant officer notify the parents of these children as to these provisions and if they refuse or neglect to send their children to school to arrest the children and take them to school and if the parents attempt to interfere with the truant officer or with the teacher in such a way as to bring themselves within the provisions of the criminal code for assault, breach of the peace or some other such offense, to have the parents prosecuted accordingly.

Dear Sir,

The Parish Priest in this district, with care of the Indian Reservation, informs me I am much disturbed about the dismissal of Miss Ellen Delaney, from the Indian School of that Reservation.

A manifest injustice has been done to Miss Delaney. In the first place she has been highly efficient and in my judgment, which is also the judgment of a former teacher, has given satisfaction in every way. In addition to this, she is a lady of refinement and culture, deeply religious, and merely an example to all.

Miss Delaney and her sister are the sole support of aged parents. Her dismissal, coming at this time causes a hardship which might easily have been avoided and which should have been avoided by anyone with a proper sense of justice and honesty of purpose.
In addition to these reasons Miss Delaney has lost her identity in the schools of the province and the twelve or more years she has taught in the Indian School at Brompton cannot warrant the teacher superannuation in this province.

It is said that 1st class teachers are required for Indian Schools today because Miss Delaney missed hers only by accident. Neither can I understand why this should have any bearing, as at Deans, Kingaclear, and at other points 2nd class teachers are employed. If this requirement be a new ruling, why in the name of justice make its effects retroactive?

If Father Ryan has engineered this change, I cannot understand what has come over him. He certainly must be losing a balance of mind. A year or two ago a most disgraceful exhibition of bullying occurred in the Dixon School. The same thing at school must be repeated at Brompton.

The different Pastors at Deans, Kingaclear, Madstock etc., care for their government charges at considerable trouble and also personal expense. We feel that we ought at least be extended the courtesy of a consultation in any contemplated changes of teachers. Neither can we understand why a teacher of the parish, in which the reservation is situated, might not be employed, rather than having one brought
from the District in which the Reverend Inspector resides.

Hoping that my plea for justice in this case may be given satisfactory consideration.

I remain

Very sincerely,

Ottawa, March 18th, 1910

Rev. Sir,

The plans and specifications for the new school houses at Woodstock and Oromocto are about completed and tenders will be called for within a short time. The plans and specifications for the Oromocto school will be sent to you when ready. These schools are both to be built on the one plan.

It will be necessary to at once take up the matter of sites for these two schools and the Department would like you to attend to this and report separately. If possible at least an acre of ground should be reserved for school purposes, so that the teaching of gardening might be taken up if desired at a later date. The site should be high and dry and easily drained. Kindly take this up at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Rev. Sir,

Referring to the proposed erection of the new school house on the Oromocto Reserve the Department would like to know whether you would undertake the inspection during the process of construction. The Department would be pleased to have you do this work if you could spare the time and make the necessary arrangements. If, however, this is impracticable steps will be taken to have an inspector appointed for the purpose.

Ottawa, June 19, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, relative to the drainage from the cellar of the Oromocto Indian Day School, and stating what you would recommend be done in the matter.

In this connection I beg to say that you may have a drain dug from the west side of the school and continued easterly to the highway. This drain should be dug about one foot below the floor level of the cellar and filled in with broken rock. This is the same arrangement as was made for drainage at the Woodstock School, which, we understand, is successful. You should arrange to have this work carried out during the coming summer holidays, and you should see that a satisfactory job is completed. The cost should be kept as low as possible, and should not exceed your estimate of approximately $75. When this work is completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Relative to the interior painting of the school building, I have to request that you will forward an estimate of the cost of having this work carried out, stating definitely what painting you would recommend be performed. When we have this information, consideration will be given to authorizing having the work done. Please give this matter your early attention, as, if it is decided to have the painting carried out, it should be done during the coming summer holidays.

Sir:

Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools, in a report on his recent inspection of the Oromocto Indian Day School, recommends that the following work be carried out during the present summer holidays. The interior woodwork of the school should be well washed, the floor thoroughly scrubbed and allowed to dry for a few days, when it should be given a coat of hot oil. He also recommends that the fence be repaired, straightened and put in good order also that a new gate be supplied, if required. You should arrange to have this work performed. Please see that the school is placed in good condition and the fence repaired before the first of September.

The Inspector requests, further, that a sand table be supplied. You may arrange to have a table, of the dimensions required, built locally and have same placed in the school before it re-opens.

In carrying out the above work, you should keep all costs as low as possible and, when completed, forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. If the lat houses require cleaning, please arrange to have this done also and see that they are in a sanitary condition.

The Inspector has spoken most highly of the services being performed by Miss Delaney, the teacher, both in the school and on the reserve. In a separate communication, you will be informed regarding an increase in salary for this teacher.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Ottawa, September 20, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, and, in reply, have to inform you that you may arrange for the supplying of milk for each of the four Indian day schools in your Agency as follows:

| School          | Qts. per school day |
|-----------------|---------------------|
| Oromocto        | 6                   |
| St. Marys       | 6                   |
| Kingsclear      | 6                   |
| Woodstock       | 8                   |

This milk may be supplied from the period beginning November 1st, next, until April 1st, following.

The cost of the milk delivered should be, if possible, eight cents per quart, and must not exceed ten cents per quart.

The teacher should keep an accurate account of the quantity of milk supplied each day. This list should be handed to you at the end of each month, and you should prepare a voucher, in triplicate, for the amount due and forward same to the Department, with the list attached showing the quantity of milk delivered at each school. A separate account should be forwarded covering the cost of the milk supplied each school.

The teacher should see that the milk is received in clean containers and that it is kept in a sanitary condition, also that the full quantity received is used by the pupils each day, without waste.

Your obedient servant,

SIR:

I recommend that the school children of Oromocto Reserve be supplied with milk for lunches through the winter months, as in previous winters, also bread and butter. It would require 5 loaves of bread and one pound of butter weekly for this school. One small nail brush is also required.

My reason for making this recommendation is that the families on this reserve seem poor and improvident. If the children were given a good morning lunch they would be in better condition to resist colds and other diseases through the winter months. The nail brush is needed to help the children to keep their hands clean.

Sir:

I beg to inform the Department that the outhouse building of the Cromcote Indian School needs repairing. The sills have rotted, and the building has settled. The doors will not open; the roof needs repairing; also the saddle board is off. There is a new box needed, as the one in use is now so rotted that it cannot be moved to be cleaned. Also, there are two lights out of the cellar windows. One of the buttments by the steps going into the school needs repairing, as the bricks have chipped, and some have fallen out.

It is impossible to give the exact cost of material and work, but I do not think it can be done for less than $30.00. The outhouse will have to be blocked up to get underneath to do the work. I would recommend that this work be done during the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

January 26, 1937.

Department of Indian Affairs,
c/o Mr. Lee MacCutcheon,
Regent Street, City.

Dear Sir:

As requested by Mr. R. Lee MacCutcheon, I inspected the Heating System at the Oromocto Reserve School, and find the fire pot is cracked in three places. The steel necks which connect the radiator to the front casting have rusted through in several places, these, have holes in them as big as a twenty-five cent piece. I consider this very dangerous if left in this condition, as it is possible for fire to pass through the tubes directly into the hot air leads. This could be temporarily repaired, with sheet iron and cement, making it safe for the balance of the heating season.

Generally speaking, I would not recommend trying to operate this furnace another season. Taking into consideration the general condition of the furnace, I also noted that the furnace has 5 hot air leads coming off, which has equivalent of 250 Sq. in. with 2-8" return leads equivalent to 100 Sq. in. This furnace should have at least another 150 Sq. in. of cold air to balance up the hot air capacity.

The cost of making the temporary repairs, of cementing the fire pot and the steel necks would be, thirteen ($13.00) Dollars.

Yours very truly,

A.J.G./B.M.

[Signature]

Fredericton, N. B.,
March 6th, 1939.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

The first of the month I instructed the Janitor of the Oromocto School to scrub the floor and oil it. I took particular pains to show him how to heat the oil and how to apply it, but to my disgust when I returned to see the work, he had put the oil on cold with a broom. The children were slipping all over the floor and the grit and sand and dust was all mixed up with the oil and tramped into the floor.

It was the worst mess I ever saw. Let me assure you, Sir, that the janitor got a severe reprimand, and if he does not do better I am going to get rid of him at the end of this month.

Friday night after school, I took a man and we went to Oromocto. I had the Indians scrub the floor and rescrub it. Then we treated it with Turpentine. I went down again Saturday morning and the floor was sand watered and scraped and treated with hot oil. It will take me some time before this floor will be as I want it. I purchased a gallon of turpentine, a gallon of Hippo oil and will send an account for the man's labour for $8.00.

Trusting the Department approves of my action,

I remain,

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent
R. Lee MacCutcheon.

Extract from Father Ryan's report on the Oromocto Indian Day School visited on June 4, 1940:

Both the interior and the exterior of this school should be painted, if at all possible. Some little repairs about school and out houses are required. The interior of out houses should be whitewashed, cleaned etc.
Ottawa,
June 22, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In the current year's appropriation an amount of $200.00 was provided for repairs and improvements at the day schools in your Agency. Yesterday I wrote to you regarding the Kingsclear School. Today I am in receipt of Father Ryan's report of the 4th instant regarding the Oromocto School in which he recommends the painting of both the interior and exterior of the school. It is doubtful if we will have funds to do this work but you might let me know the cost of painting both the interior and exterior. A separate estimate should be forwarded as we might be able to do only one. The Inspector also states that some small repairs are required and that the toilets should be whitewashed. These will not involve any heavy expenditure and you may arrange for the necessary work before the schools re-open after the summer holidays.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. R. Lee MacCutcheon,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir,

At this time, I hesitate to request the Department to expend any monies on anything which we can possibly get along without; however, in the Oromocto Indian Day School, we have a steel ceiling and although the interior of this school was painted in 1934, the paint is peeling and dropping from the ceiling and certainly needs to be done over. This would be a job for a painter with an Indian helper. The ceilings will have to be steel brushed and of course, it will involve an expenditure of more than 50 dollars.

I would ask permission to have a painter (one recommended to me by the correct persons) give me an estimate of this, so that I may submit same to the Department.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent
R. Lee MacCutcheon.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir;

Reference your letter dated June 22, File No. 56-3-5 wherein you state that the year's appropriation for repair and improvements for the Indian Day Schools in this Agency amounts to $200 dollars. I note that Father Ryan recommends that the Oromocto School be painted both on the interior and exterior. This is quite out of the question with the amount of money we have. The school is in need of paint on the outside. The interior, with the exception of the ceiling is in very good condition, and even the outside of this school does not need painting as badly as the school at Kingsclear; however, I would ask for authority to expend $50 dollars at the Oromocto School for cleaning walls, floors, desks, outhouses, etc., Indians to do the work.

Attached please find an estimate supplied by Austin Smith, white man of Oromocto, recommended to me by the correct persons. I would ask authority to employ Mr. Smith to remove the old paint from the ceiling and repaint it. Material and labour to cost $50.45. The estimated cost of work to be done in the four schools $120.45. This will leave a small surplus for making small repairs during the coming year and I feel under the circumstances, that with the painting of the
the ceiling at Cromocto and cleaning of the other schools, we can get along very nicely this year.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent
R. Lee MacCutcheon.

Indian Affairs

April 14, 1887

Sir,

I have just had a visit from the Chief of the Red Bank Indians who said he has requested me on behalf of his band to ask that a school house be erected at Red Bank. I proceeded to bring the matter to your attention and I take this opportunity of doing so. I am, however, of the opinion that a school house is not very much needed by this band. There is an English school within two miles from the reserve and if the Indians were very desirous of educating their children there would be no difficulty in sending them to this school.

The Indian School at Bel Ground where there is a much larger Indian population is not a success owing to the indifference of the Indians. During the last quarter there were only eight pupils enrolled and an average attendance of five. It is questionable whether the work done at this school justifies the expenditure for teachers' salaries. On the other hand, the work being done in the schools at Point Church and
Big Cone where the Indians affect to take more interest in the matter of education.

Some opinion that a school at Red Bank would not be a success. In any case of the Indians there are directors of education whose children I can see no reason why they should not take advantage of the white schools in the vicinity.

Yours obdly,

[Signature]

Sir,

In reply to official letter of the 10th instant, I have to report that I have on more than one occasion called on the Indians of Red Bank having children of school age and requested them to send their children to school. There are two white schools in the vicinity at either of which they could have attended. Tenas did send one of his children for some time and informed me that he paid for their tuition himself. I informed him and the others that the Department would pay these bills if they were sent me and asked him to send them but he stated he would not ask for payment, that he was able to pay himself. At that time he was very much dissatisfied because the people would not build an Indian school at Red Bank. The next time I visited the reserve I again brought up the subject with him and he then said he would send me the bills for tuition, but he never did so. At that time the both white schools in the vicinity were quite willing to receive Indian pupils and I have never heard that they have since refused to do so. I very much doubt his statement that any pupil has ever been refused but will at once make inquiries. Tenas is still agitating to have an Indian school at Red Bank and I think the object

REPORT OF REV. J.J. RYAN ON THE SCHOOLS IN HIS INSPECTORATE

THE BAND DAY SCHOOL:

The attendance at school is fairly good but it would be in the interests of those attending were these not of age excluded from the school as naturally they are a distraction to the pupils. There has been very little progress made in this school since my last visit and the examination of those present showed they took but little interest in their work. Discipline and deportment were poor and the dress of the children in many cases slovenly.

Miss Eva Cermier is the teacher here. Not having taught previously to accepting her present position her methods of teaching is not of the best and regret to say that I am of the opinion that it never will improve.

March, 1919.

Ottawa, July 22, 1919.

MEMORANDUM.

The engagement of Miss Ena A. Cormier, teacher of the Red Bank Indian school, New Brunswick, ended on the 30th. of June, last. She had had charge of this school since it was opened on the first of September, 1914.

The late Superintendent of Indian Schools, the Rev. J. J. Ryan, in his last report on this school, which was made in March of this year, stated that Miss Cormier, not having taught previously to accepting her present position, her method of teaching is not of the best, and he regretted to say that he was of the opinion that it would never improve. He also stated that there had been very little progress made in the school since his last visit and the examination of the pupils showed that they took but little interest in their work, and the discipline and deportment were poor and the dress of the children in many cases slovenly.

Owing to the unsatisfactory conditions as stated, by Father Ryan, Mr. Superintendent Sheridan was instructed, in May last, to advise the teacher, Miss Cormier, that her services would not be required after the 30th. of June, next, the end of the school year.

The Rev. F. C. Ryan, the new Superintendent of Indian Schools, was instructed to advise the Department if he knew of another teacher for this school, but up to the present no applications have been received, and it is doubtful if a qualified teacher can be obtained at the salary allowed, viz.- $400.00 per annum.

Martin Benson.

Ottawa, March 29, 1920.

Sir,-

A report has been received from Miss Isaacs, teacher of the Red Bank Indian Day School, in which she states that the school was closed since February 26th on account of a shortage of fuel.

It is considered that an ample supply of coal was furnished for the use of this school and, unless there is great waste or the coal is being stolen, the Department cannot understand why so much coal is consumed at this school.

You will be good enough to purchase a supply sufficient for the needs of the school till the warm weather arrives. You should obtain prices from a number of dealers and purchase the coal from the one quoting the lowest price. In making the purchase you should be guided in all respects by the requirements of the War Purchasing Commission. You will be good enough to give this matter your prompt attention and have the coal supplied to the school at once.

Miss Isaacs states that the janitor, Chief John Tenass, has resigned and appointed another man, Harry Condo, who does not perform his work in a satisfactory manner. You will also be good enough to look into this question of the janitor and advise the Department.

The teacher states that the place where the coal is kept was open all winter. Some arrangement should be made to keep the coal under lock and key and the janitor should be responsible to see that there is no waste and that none of the coal is stolen.

John Sheridan, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.

Chief,

The Department has been informed of the trouble that you have been occasioning the teacher of the Red Bank Indian Day School. Miss Isaacs is performing her duties satisfactorily to the Department and to the majority of the Indians of the band, and the children have made good progress since she took charge of the school.

I have, therefore, to inform you that it is your duty as Chief to do all in your power to assist the teacher, instead of stirring up trouble against her. Both yourself and your wife should cease causing any further disturbance or interfering with the work of the teacher, and you should endeavour to help the teacher in every way possible and encourage the Indian parents to send their children regularly to school. Ottawa, June 15, 1920.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant enclosing a petition from a number of the Indians of the Red Bank Band in which they request that the services of Miss Martha Isaacs be retained as teacher of the Indian day school on that reserve.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of the trouble that has occurred between the teacher and the Chief, it was considered that it would be in the best interests of all concerned that a change in teacher be made for this school. However, as the Indians express a desire to retain Miss Isaacs' services the Department will consent to her remaining for a further period. Should further trouble, however, occur after this school re-opens in September, next, a new teacher will have to be secured. Miss Isaacs may, therefore, remain in charge at Red Bank and Miss Taylor is to remain at Eel Ground. You will be good enough to inform these teachers accordingly. Miss Isaacs should understand that, if there are any further complaints, it will be necessary to make a change at the Red Bank School.

Your remarks re. Mr. Ward, the truant officer at Eel Ground, have been noted, and Mr. Superintendent Sheridan is being informed that, as this man has given no service, his salary cannot be paid for the current quarter.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. F. C. Ryan,
Inspector of Indian Schools,
Maliseet, N.B.
Ottawa, June 15, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Ryan has forwarded a petition from the Indians of the Red Bank Band, in which they request that Miss Martha Isaacs, teacher of the school on that reserve, be retained. They state that the Chief is the only one who wishes a change.

It was considered that, in view of the trouble that had occurred during the past year between Miss Isaacs and the Chief, it would be better to arrange for a transfer. However, as the Indians express a wish to retain her services, the Department will agree to her remaining for a further period on the understanding, however, that should any further trouble occur a change of teachers will have to be made. Inspector Ryan is being informed accordingly.

On May 10th, last, you were requested to state whether you considered that it would be advisable to appoint a new truant officer and caretaker for this school in place of the Chief. If this were done it might avoid trouble that was occasioned in the past. The Department will be pleased to have your views regarding the appointment of another truant officer. The Chief should be made to understand that he is not to interfere with the work of the teacher and that it is expected that he will use his best endeavours to persuade the Indian parents to send their children regularly to school.

Your obedient servant,

J. B. Sheridan, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.

Ottawa, May 11, 1921.

Sir,

In a letter just received from Miss Martha Isaacs, teacher of the Red Bank Indian Day School, it appears that Chief Michael Tenass is hindering the work of the teacher by interfering with the lessons given by her to the pupils.

You will be good enough to point out to the Chief that the Department expects him to do everything in his power to assist the teacher and make this school a success.

As far as the Department is aware, Miss Isaacs is following out the programme prescribed for Indian day schools, and, if the chief continues to retard her work, the Department will be obliged to consider his deposition.

You will be good enough to inform the chief at as early a date as possible.

Your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

I am pleased to state that Miss Allen opened her school on the 30th. Your letter of the 26th, of Dec. last gave her until the 29th at Normal School. The heavy storms so delayed trains, that she was kept over another day.

Imagine the Chief living but a few feet from my door writing the Dept. for such information, and the Dept. on the other hand giving cognizance to same. It is just this that gives so much trouble, embolden by this recognition of the Dept., the next step, the Chief will rule the "SCHOOL."

To my mind, how much nicer it would have been for the Dept. to have diplomatically referred the CHIEF to the Insp. of Ind. Schools. Proper relations between all could be maintained, which means better order, government and success. I have always been very careful to send all such correspondence from Chiefs to the Dept. that came through my hands. I believe in giving the CHIEFS their place of recognition among themselves, but "INCH" beyond that, and every organization of order in the Dept. from the highest to the lowest will feel the encroachment.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sirs:

On several occasions, our Red Bank, Ind. day school has been visited in past years by two of our Ind. women (I am pleased to say their standing on the Reserve is not very good,) who, ever some trifling affair re. their children, have during school hours, used very vile language against the teacher & & before the pupils -- Just this week such has been repeated again, I have resolved to put an end to such at once, before taking the step I thought to consult with the Dept. and have the Dept. write a letter to each of the offenders - both are receiving Gov. aid.

The guilty parties are Mrs Mary Sylvester Ward, and Mrs Philip Young, (Red Bank, Ind. Reserve). This case will get them another case that developed this week - that of Raymond Young, the 13 year old son of this famous Mrs. P. Young,

the teacher, Mrs. Keene, lost her watch. It was reported that the said Raymond Young found same, I brought him & his father to my office, after some trouble the young lad said he found the watch and hid same under an old tree, later he said he sold the watch to a constable but I do not know. The officer took the boy before the police magistrate, the Matonet boy was summoned - then at court - the said Raymond Young told the court he only said that he sold this boy the watch thinking he would get clear, however he informed the court, that he found the watch and hid it under a tree, so the court sent him back with Copp - the police officer, but no watch was found, I called up the Police magistrate re. the case, he said he could do nothing, as the young lad lied in every way, so that nothing could be done.

On account of the scandal before all the school children, I had the teacher give the Ind. children a good lecture, and order this child to leave the school room until something could be done to clear up the matter.

We fear he sold the watch and we are offering a reward for its recovery and publishing it all over the country. He told me he sold it for $50 cash.

He is a bright child, and the first Ind. child that I have ever met that will look you in the face and lie as fast as he can talk. We are certainly up against a "SOMETHING" - Mrs Keene is about discouraged.

Any suggestions on the subject of the above would be gratefully received. This Young family draws AID MONEY, and for this very boy, again I fear to let him at school with the other children, -- I really do not know what to do with the case.

J. C. Ryan
