Ottawa, April 23, 1928.

Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Rev. Father Ryan, in which he states that on several occasions two Indian women of the Reserve visited the Red Bank School and caused a disturbance. He states the names of these women are Mrs. Mary Sylvester Ward and Mrs. Philip Young. Mrs. Ward's last offence in disturbing the school was on the 19th instant. Father Ryan states that the teacher ordered Mrs. Ward to leave the school, but she said that she would stay as long as she wanted, and she kept the school in an uproar for ten minutes. He states that both these families are receiving relief, and asks that some action be taken to prevent further disturbance on the part of these women, and that the relief granted them be cancelled, pending their future good conduct.

I have to request that on the occasion of your next visit to this Reserve you will enquire into the case of the disturbance at the school, and notify these women that, if there is any further complaint, steps will be taken to have them prosecuted by a magistrate. It is thought that you will be visiting Red Bank in the near future in connection with various matters affecting this Reserve, and you should then deal fully with the complaints above referred to. These two women should be made to understand that they are not to interfere with the teacher, or with the work of the classes in the school.

Rev. Father Ryan further states that the teacher lost her watch, and it was reported that one of the Indian pupils, Raymond Young, a son of one of the women mentioned above, found same. Father Ryan had the constable take this boy before the police magistrate, but the case was dismissed for want of the necessary evidence as to the boy's guilt. You might make enquiry into this matter also.

It would be advisable to consult Father Ryan and the teacher regarding all the above complaints. After your visit, you should report fully to the Department any action taken. We are informing Father Ryan that the matters complained of have been placed in your hands.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

"This is a very small school. There are some 2 or 3 too large to go, or will be next term; then there are 3 or 4 who really should be in the Shubenacadie Indian School; in this case, we would not require the said school for a few years. If 5 or 6 children were sent to Shubenacadie School, the Red Bank School could be closed. In the end, I think 4 or 5 of these children will have to be sent as their surroundings are very poor."

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated June 28th., File 55-5-1 referring to report of Inspector Ryan on the Red Bank Indian Day school, with a suggestion that it might be closed for a few years. In reply I beg to say that I have looked into this matter and I find that there are Eleven children between the ages of 6 and 13 years attending school, and then there are 4 other children aged 4 and 5 years on the reserve, besides quite a number of still younger children.

I cannot see why this school should be closed as the children are all making good progress, they attend regularly and have a very efficient teacher. The school building is in good condition and everything seems to be in order for continuing the school.

In regard to the necessity of sending any more of the children of the Red Bank reserve to the Shubenacadie school I cannot see where it exists, at present.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary
Indian Agent
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

My dear Father Ryan:

I admire your constant solicitude for the welfare of Indian children of the province and hope you will succeed in re-opening the School on their Reserve.

Extract from Father Ryan's report on the Red Bank Indian Day School visited on June 14, 1940:

This is a very small school with now only 11 pupils and two of those are very stolid, while two others are about to leave school. There will be no new pupils to enter. We cannot expect much from this school in higher education.

Mrs. Kehoe is a wonderful teacher for this school. Her years are against her for a large school. She has done wonderful work in domestic science. I think it would be better to keep this school open for another year, then if the pupils get below 9, we could send them to the Red Bank white school.

Memorandum:

RED BANK INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Date of Inspection - September 8, 1949.

Location of School
This school is situated near the small village of Red Bank, N.B. It is a short distance from Newcastle, N.B. A road passes right by the school.

Condition of School
This is an old school but still serviceable for some years. It is well lighted with eight windows, mostly along one wall. It has been recently painted inside and next year Mr. Blakey will requisition for paint for the outside. A new roof has been put on the school and on the whole it is in sound condition.

There is a teacher's residence also but this is at present occupied by an old lady who is janitor. The teacher lives on her farm which is located nearby.

Teacher
Mrs. Florence Hogan who has second-class certificate with 12 years of provincial experience. She is a capable woman and in time should fit well into this position. She is 43 years of age and will probably remain at this school for some years.

Classroom work
I gave these children the usual standardized test and found they did well in spelling and arithmetic but were weak
in silent reading and vocabulary work. As this teacher is new to the work, I spent most of my time in assisting her with her own problems.

Recommendations

1. Order new desks.
2. Paint exterior next year.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Ottawa, January 30, 1917.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to your salary as teacher of the Red Bank Day School for the December quarter, last.

In reply I beg to say that the return of attendance for the December quarter has not yet reached the Department. You should make out this return on the proper form and forward it through Mr. Agent Sheridan and upon receipt of the same by the Department a cheque for the amount of salary due will be sent you.

I may say that the return of attendance for the September quarter has also not been received by the Department. You should prepare a return showing the attendance for this quarter also and forward it through your local Agent. Kindly give this matter your prompt attention, so that any balance of salary due you can be paid.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Ottawa, April 16, 1918.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 11th instant, in which you inform the Department that a cheque for $100.00 sent you in payment of your salary as teacher of the Red Bank Indian Day School for the March quarter last, has been lost or destroyed and requesting that a duplicate be sent.

In reply I beg to say that before a duplicate cheque can be issued it will be necessary for you to furnish a bond of indemnity for double the amount of the lost cheque. Two sureties are required on your bond. A blank form of the bond required is enclosed herewith which you are to use for this purpose. A form of the bond, filled in in pencil, for your guidance, is also enclosed. It will be necessary for you to have this bond executed in the presence of a Notary Public or a Justice of the Peace.

When the bond of indemnity has been completed by yourself and your two sureties and the declaration of the witnesses completed, you should return the bond to the Department, when, if found correct, a duplicate cheque will then be issued in place of the one which you lost.

Your obedient servant

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Miss Ena A. Cormier,
Teacher,
Red Bank Indian Day School
Sunny Corner,
N. B.

Sir.—
Would you kindly inform me if it is necessary for me to make out a pay sheet for the teachers salaries, or is the quarterly report all that is needed.

I have had a letter from Miss Allen of RED Bank saying she was disappointed in the amount she received $60.00. In view of this I began to think that perhaps it was necessary to have a separate sheet. Ottawa, Jan. 26, 1923.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 18th instant, I beg to say that the December Quarter salary cheque of Miss Allen, teacher of Red Bank School amounted to $125.00 and was sent to her at Red Bank, N.B. on Jan. 11th.

The cheque for $60.00, to which you refer in your letter, covered the amount due her for bonus for the months of September, October, November and December. As you are no doubt aware teachers in Indian Day Schools are being paid a bonus during the present fiscal year at the rate of $15.00 a month for each teaching month.

For your information I may say that it is not necessary for you to make out pay sheets for the teachers as these are typed in the Department. The quarterly return is all that is required.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Dpt. of Indian Education.

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Sir:

Sir;-

I have the honour to report that the Indians of the Rei Bank Indian Band through their Chief, are asking for a school on the said Reserve. They state, that there are 14 children that are now ready to go to school and are unable to do so on account of their being no school upon the said reserve and no white school in the immediate proximity.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Ottawa, May 6, 1914.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo stating that the Indians of the Red Bank Band are anxious to have a school established on their reserve.

In reply I beg to say that, if you are satisfied that there will be enough children to school age to justify the Department in re-opening the school there, it would be inclined to do so, provided there is a building suitable for the purpose. If the old building is still available I should like to have an estimate of the probable cost of putting it in repair to open the school after the summer holidays and you should also state whether it would be possible to engage the services of a suitable teacher to take charge.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. A. IRVING, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.

Sir;—

I have the honour to acknowledge your communication of the above number of the Sixth Instant in re. Rei Bank Indian school, and in reply I may say, that I am making enquiries as to the possibility of getting a suitable house for a school house. I do not think that the old building is in existence, as my attention has never been called to it at any time I visited the reserve.

I do not consider that there will be any difficulty in obtaining the services of a suitable teacher to take charge of this school, and have now already a person in view.

As soon as I can get definite information in regard to the building, I shall communicate with you again upon the matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir:

In further reference to your communication of the above number regarding the opening of a school on the Rei Bank Indian Reserve, the Chief writes me, in answer to my enquiry, that there are no available building that can be repaired for this purpose, and he is desirous that a new school house be erected.

I think however, that I may be able to secure a suitable building and intend visiting the reserve in the course of a few days and will then report more fully upon the matter. I may also say, that the Rev. Father Duffy who is the R.C. clergyman at Rei Bank, is desirous of having a school on this reserve.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Superintendent.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir;—

In further reference to your communication of the above number in re. the establishing of the Rei Bank Indian School, I may say, that the small house of Mr. Henry Cloud upon the reserve can be secured at a rental of $6.00 per month. It will require about $25.00 to repair the same in addition to small outbuildings which will have to be erected. These repairs must be done at the expense of the Department.

I would suggest in the event of the trial school being opened, that the seats and desks now used at the trial school at Eel River Reserve be transferred to this school at Rei Bank, and that new metal desks and seats metal bottom and hardwood tops, be procured for the new school at Eel River. I may also say, that I do not think there will be any difficulty in securing a suitable teacher to take the school.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Superintendent.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, July 27th, 1914

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant with further reference to the re-establishment of a school at Red Bank and stating that you can secure a small house for the accommodation of the school at a rental of $6.00 - a month, but that it will require about $25.00 worth of repairs in addition to some small outbuildings which ought to be erected. In reply I beg to say that provided you are satisfied that you will be able to secure a suitable teacher to take charge of this school, the repairs may be made and the Department will pay the rent specified and you may have the seats and desks now in use in the school at Bel River Reserve transferred to Red Bank.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I would ask you to let me know whether you have any definite information as to whether Henry Cloud has taken possession of his house and that it will not be available for school purposes. The building used for school purposes is unsuited for the work. It is too small and the children are huddled uncomfortably close together.

Sir:

Ottawa, January 6, 1921.

Sir,

Three Indians from the Red Bank Reserve, who visited the Department today, complained of the way the coal supplied for the use of the Red Bank Indian Day School has been taken away. They said that Stanley Doran, the blacksmith, had stated that, on the authority of the Chief, he had removed five bags of coal, which he had not returned. The Chief had no authority to grant permission to anyone to take away coal and you will be good enough to inform him accordingly. You should inform Doran that it is expected that he will return the quantity of coal taken by him at once. The Indians and others should understand that this coal is supplied for the use of the school only and must not be used for other purposes.

In November, last, you submitted an estimate of the cost of erecting a combined coal and wood shed for this school, but, as the price was considered excessive, you were requested to endeavour to obtain a price for another cheaper type of building. The Indians request that the labour in erecting a combined shed which would serve the purpose be performed by the Indians. It is now too late in the season to do anything this winter, but the erection of this shed should not be lost sight of and you should draw it to the attention of the Department in the spring. It is considered that, if the lumber were supplied, the Indians could perform the labour themselves and the total cost should not exceed $75.00, as the Department has had similar work done at the school for that amount. It will be necessary in the construction of the shed to provide separate bins for the coal and wood. The bin for the coal should be floored. You should try and have the necessary arrangements made to have this work undertaken in the spring and should be prepared to furnish an estimate of the material required and the cost of the labour when you bring the matter to the attention of the Department next spring.

There is no well in connection with the school and I shall be pleased if you will submit an estimate of the cost of having a suitable well dug or drilled, including the cost of the pump and other material required.

The Department will be pleased to hear from you in due course regarding the above matters.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

Reverend Father Ryan in a report on his recent inspection of the Red Bank Indian Day School states as follows:

"I think this makes the fourth time I have asked for a cupboard to care for school material. It is badly needed. You should arrange during the present holidays to have the interior wood work and floor thoroughly scrubbed and cleaned. You should also arrange to have any repairs required to the out houses performed, and also to have them thoroughly cleaned and placed in a sanitary condition.

June 26, 1922.

Stove should be repaired. A new bottom part and coal grate purchased, also latch for stove door.

An axe and two lbs. of soap required.

The hardwood floor in school should have two good coats of oil.

The interior of school should be well washed.

A new lock required for school door.

August 3rd, 1922.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Ryan in a report on his inspection of the Red Bank Indian Day School states as follows: "Stove should be repaired. A new bottom part and coal grate purchased, also latch for stove door. An axe and two pounds of soap required. The hardwood floor in school should have two good coats of oil. The interior of school should be well washed. A new lock required for school door. The interior of teacher's house painted. A toilet set for teacher's house purchased. Double windows should be purchased for school. There are none and present windows very open".

I shall be pleased if you will arrange to have the stove repaired. You should obtain a new bottom part and coal grate. You may also purchase an axe and two pounds of soap. Interior woodwork of the class-room should be well washed, the floors should be scrubbed and given two coats of oil. You should have a new lock placed on the school door and you may purchase a cheap toilet set for the teacher's residence. With reference to the double windows for the school I should be glad if you would furnish an estimate of the cost of having these supplied. We are not prepared to authorize the painting of the interior of the teacher's house.

Both the work and supplies which have been authorized should be completed before the school re-opens for the fall term. No undue expenditure should be incurred and properly certified vouchers in duplicate should be forwarded to cover the cost of the repairs and for the supplies.

Yours truly,

John Sheridan, Bsc.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Buctouche, N.B.

I shall be pleased if you will look into this matter, and, if you consider the Inspector's suggestion to be a satisfactory solution of the difficulty experienced by the children, you should arrange for the installation of the tin around the two sides and the back of the stove to a height sufficient for the purpose. We desire that conditions in the school room be made as comfortable as possible for both the pupils and the teacher, and this matter should receive your early attention.

Ottawa, July 14th, 1924.

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his inspection of the Red Bank Indian Day School, recommends that the interior of the school building be well washed with soap and water and, when dry, given a good coat of hard varnish. He also requests that the interior of the teacher's house be painted. This building has not been in use for about two years, and, as a new teacher is being engaged who will occupy the house, Father Ryan recommends that the building be placed in good condition. He further requests that the woodshed be painted, and that several of the desks be cut down to provide suitable seating accommodation for the smaller children.

I shall be pleased if you will make the necessary arrangements to have the interior of the school building thoroughly cleaned and given one coat of varnish. You may also arrange to have the interior of the teacher's house painted. Only the work considered necessary by you in this house should be carried out. A brighter colour of paint than that at present on the interior of the building should be used. You should also arrange to have any painting required to the woodshed carried out, and the desks cut down to meet the requirements. It would be well for you to consult Father Ryan regarding the above painting, and it may be possible that he can arrange for the labour required. You, however, should arrange for the purchase of the materials. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred, and proper vouchers should be forwarded covering the cost of the paint, varnish, etc., supplied and for the labour employed. This work should, if possible, be completed during the present summer holidays, and it should, therefore, receive your early attention.

You may purchase and have delivered 20 yards of gingham of a good quality to be used by the teacher in having the older girls make up aprons and dresses. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering this expenditure.

The necessary quantity of khaki which you have received should be supplied this school.

Inspector Ryan states that he has a good teacher in view for this school for next year. You will be advised later when the appointment has been made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N.B.

Memorandum

Mr. McLean:

On 23rd September last I visited and inspected the school buildings on the Red Bank Indian Reserve.

It will be necessary next summer to carry out the following repairs, namely:

Re-shingle the east side of the roof using creosote stained shingles and also creosote the west side of the roof over old shingles. The exterior walls require painting with two coats of good paint.

There is a small residence provided for the teacher. This building also requires to be painted with two coats of paint on the outside. We have very fine buildings on this reserve and when painted they will be a credit to the Department.

The interior of the school building is sheeted with pine sheeting and has hard wood floor. The desks were in good condition and the classroom presented a very attractive appearance.

Our Agent could arrange next spring for the labour in painting the buildings and also for the purchase of the paint, oil, etc., required. I am unable to give an estimate of what this work would cost, but strongly recommend that it be carried out next summer. While at the school I was accompanied by Mr. Agent Hudson and Rev. Father Ryan. I authorized the Agent to have a small table installed in the classroom for the cutting of garments and also to buy a small quantity of sewing material and slates. Dear Sir:

With reference to the heating of the Red Bank Indian Day school, it has been done with a coal heater in previous years. The heater now has to be renewed before the weather gets cold, and I was thinking that it will be less expensive if a wood burning stove was installed instead of coal. This school is located in a district where there is abundance of good wood available and I don't see why a considerable expense could not be saved by using wood instead of coal. In the first place a wood-burning stove will only cost about half as much as a coal stove, and I know the wood will cost less.

If you have already arranged for the purchase of the coal it will be inconvenient to change your plans, but if not, I would recommend that wood would be used in future instead of coal for this school. Please let me know what you consider would best in this case.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Repairs to Indian Day School and Teachery,
Red Bank Reserve, North'ld County, N. B.

In reply to your letter of the 23rd instant, file number 55-5-5 (E.1) regarding the renewing of the roofs of the above mentioned buildings. I wish to say that the two firms mentioned did not quote exactly the same prices but the difference is negligible. In both instances quotations are subject to change to prevailing prices on date of delivery and are not F.O.B. school. Delivery of these materials would be made to the school by agency truck. Indian labour will be employed but I know of no Indian on the reserve, capable of taking charge of this work.

The sum of $297.50 is a careful estimate of the cost of labour to complete this work but I can not guarantee that this amount will not be exceeded.

In our letters of April 23rd and April 26th instant, further authority was requested for repairs to school buildings at Burnt Church and Big Cove Reserves. If all of this work can not be authorized this year, I respectfully suggest that the Burnt Church buildings be given priority.

Memorandum:

RED BANK INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

Date of Inspection - September 8, 1949.

Location of School
This school is situated near the small village of Red Bank, N.B. It is a short distance from Newcastle, N.B. A road passes right by the school.

Condition of School
This is an old school but still serviceable for some years. It is well lighted with eight windows, mostly along one wall. FREDERICTON, NOVEMBER 25TH, 1901

Sir,

With reference to the return from the teacher Miss M. D. Smith of the St. Mary's Reserve, N.B., School, I have to inform that owing to a case of Tuberculosis being in the family of her mother and other members of the family, she has been ordered to remain at home until such time as there is no possibility of further cases being transmitted from their present state. It is uncertain when the patient will be available for treatment. The patient in family is Miss Smith's brother. He returned home from the place where he was in hospital on Tuesday night the 3rd inst. Miss Smith taught the school on the following day, but on learning of the case it ordered the school to be closed at the 5th hour and fumigated so that the school has been closed since then for fourteen teaching days.

I am pleased to report that the symptoms of contagion have been, and there are no indications of further cases, and anticipate an improvement therewith.

Blessings on thee, little man
Barefoot boy, with cheek of tan

O, for boyhood's painless play
Sleep that wakes in laughing day,
Health that mocks the doctor's rules.

Knowledge never learned of schools,
Of the wild bees morning chase,
Of the wild flowers time and place,
Flight of fowl and habitude
Of the tenants of the wood.

How the robin feed her young
How the orioles nest is hung,
Where the whitest lilies blow,
Where the freshest berries grow;
Where the grape-nut trials its vine,
Where the wood-grapes cluster shine.

With thy turned-up pantaloons,
And thy merry whistled tune;
With thy red lip redder still
Kissed by strawberries on the hills.

With the sunshine on thy face,
Through thy torn brims jaunty grace
From my heart I give thee joy.

O, for boyhood's time of June
Crowding years in one brief moon,
When all things I heard or saw
Me, their master, waited for.
I was rich in flowers and trees,
Humming birds and honey bee;
Every morn shall lead thee through
Fresh baptism of dew.
Every evening from thy feet
Shall the cool wind kiss the heat.

Ah! that thou couldst know thy joy
Ere it passes, barefoot boy!
Cheerily then, my little man
Live and laugh as boyhood can.

Ah! that thou couldst laugh at the brook
Know thy joy for my delight
Ere it passes, barefoot boy through the day

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

In the petition hereunder Miss Mary T. Hughes, teacher of the St. Mary's School, N.B., requests an increase in her salary.

Miss Hughes was appointed teacher of this school on August 28th, 1911, at a salary of $350.00, which was increased to $400.00 on January 1st, 1914, and further increased to $450.00 on July 1st, 1917. This is the salary she is now receiving, together with the bonus at the rate of $150.00 per annum. Miss Hughes states that the salaries paid to the public school teachers in the vicinity doing similar work to herself are now $900.00 per annum and that they have petitioned for and expect to receive an increase of $200.00. Miss Hughes requests that her annual salary be increased to $1000.00.

There is an enrolment of 24 pupils at this school, with an average attendance of 19.

Miss Hughes holds a Second Class Professional License and a special certificate for the teaching of physical culture.

The Inspector states that she has done especially good work since assuming charge of this school and that he does not think that her work could be improved on. She teaches the girls sewing and knitting and lessons are also given in hygiene. She also visits and advises the women on the reserve. The Inspector also states that the school is well managed and that, if we could get the same results in all our schools in New Brunswick, it would be most encouraging.

I would
I would recommend that Miss Hughes be granted an increase of $100.00 from the first of January, last, as there is no doubt that the present salary paid her is inadequate. She maintains the best average attendance of any of the schools in New Brunswick, and the reports on her work have always been satisfactory. If the above increase is allowed this will give her a salary at the rate of $550.00, which, with the bonus of $150.00, will make a total of $700.00.

I beg to submit the above for your consideration.

There were 21 in attendance the day I visited the school; the average attendance is 20, with a total enrolment of 25; the discipline is nil; the attendance is O.K.; and the enrolment all that can be desired.

Dear Sirs:

In making my FALL tour of the Inspectors of our Ind. schools along the St. John river this week, I found that Miss Hughes, teacher in the North Deven Ind. school had thrown out our Cerena Readers and introduced the Canadian readers, also introduced the Ontario grammar, stating it was the desire of the Dept. to do so, and that I gave her orders to change the readers.

Grammar, perhaps your Dept. did not order such a change. Again she informed me that the Dept. intended to make further changes & in the curriculum of the N.B. Ind. schools.

I might here add that our N.B. Ind. schools are enjoying a prosperity that is not surpassed in any other Prov. in Canada, but if our CURRICULUM which is the same as the White schools of N.B. is allowed to be laceraed and undermined, to suit the whim and fancy of every teacher, -as was the case when I took over these said Ind. schools,-then nothing but "CHAOTIC CONDITIONS" must reign and our present prosperity annulled.

Kindly inform Miss Hughes to fellow my directions like all our teachers are doing and have our Cerena Readers replaced in her school, also the N.E. Grammar.

Dear Mr. McGill:

My attention has just been directed to the fact that Miss Hughes, who has given very faithful and efficient service for twenty-two years, as teacher of the St. Marys, now North Devon, Indian Day School, has received notice, dated June 21, 1933, from the Reverend Father F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, at Red Bank, Northumberland County, to the effect that it has been considered advisable to engage a first-class teacher for the term beginning September next, and therefore her services would not be required after the 30th of June, 1933. It is intimated to Miss Hughes that the Indian Department will allow her upon retiring a gratuity equal to two months salary.

Now ostensibly the reason given for Miss Hughes' retirement is that the services of a first-class teacher are required. My information is that such is not the case and that Miss Hughes has done excellent work. As a matter of fact, I am advised that in days gone by her pupils have led all the other Indian pupils in the Province in essay contests, domestic science and manual science work, and other spheres of educational activity.

I think it rather rough, that after twenty-two years of faithful service she should be
dismissed peremptorily on a week's notice. If the school were being closed up, if there were any complaint against the efficiency of her service, or if any other good reason were assigned as to why she should be dismissed, one could understand the action of the Inspector, but such being not the case, I do protest against her dismissal, and would request you very earnestly to have the order countermanded, and Miss Hughes retained in the employ of the Department, especially because she has given universal satisfaction over there.

In his letter to her, the Reverend Father states that they are grateful for her 22 years of service and it is an absolute fact that there is no complaint against her.

It is a pretty serious matter to turn a woman of her age out of her employment at the present time. As a matter of fact it is rather a cruel thing.

I have no doubt that if it had been intimated to Miss Hughes that she should have what is known as a first-class license she could easily qualify, and would be prepared to do so. I have therefore to very earnestly request that the order given by the Inspector be countermanded and that Miss Hughes be retained in her position. If it is necessary for her to qualify as a first-class teacher she will do so. The difference between a first and second class license in New Brunswick is not so marked as to make it impossible for her to qualify.

I assure you that there is absolutely no politics behind this request. Miss Hughes has probably never voted for me and probably never will, and there is certainly one occasion on which I am quite sure she did not vote for me, so I am not writing for any personal motive, but really out of a sense of justice to her, and I appeal to you to review the circumstances in the same sense.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

Replying to your memorandum of the 26th instant, with reference to a communication received from Mr. R. B. Hanson, M. P., regarding the dismissal of Miss Mary T. Hughes, teacher of the St. Mary's Indian Day School, North Devon, N. B., I attach hereto, as requested, copies of Mr. Hanson's letter to Dr. McGill of the 14th instant, Mr. Williams' reply of the 15th instant and a further letter from Mr. Hanson of the 21st instant, to which no reply has yet been made.

During the past two or three years, Reverend F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, following his semi-annual visits of inspection to this school, has reported adversely regarding Miss Hughes' services. A report, dated May 16, 1933, states as follows:

"I wish Miss Hughes would resign to make way for a younger teacher. I think the Department has been more than generous to have retained Miss Hughes' services so long. I would be pleased to see her have the school if better work could be done. However, I have waited years for this, but all in vain. We should get an up-to-date teacher with modern ideas of teaching. Her day has long passed away."

Father Ryan was informed that, in view of lengthy service, the Department would continue Miss Hughes' employment during the school year ending June 30th, last - her further retention to depend upon the reports of his inspection during the past school year. He visited and inspected this school on May 30, 1933, and reported as follows:

"I really do not consider that this school has produced the required advanced work for some years. I would certainly suggest a younger teacher, who will engender new life in this school. We must put new life in this school and get more advanced work. We can fill this school by a good first class teacher, which can easily be procured for the same money."

As stated in Mr. Williams' reply to Mr. Hanson, of the 13th instant, the Department wrote Father Ryan, requesting him to give further consideration to the question of dispensing with Miss Hughes' services.

- His reply
His reply, dated the 11th instant, copy of which is attached hereto, was that Miss Hughes is not able to give this school more attention than she can. Only a certain standard can be reached and beyond that it is impossible for her to make progress. He considered that, in the best interests of the work, a change of teacher should be made. He was therefore instructed to notify Miss Hughes that her services would not be required after June 30th, last.

Miss Mary L. Murdoch, R. N., Public Health Nurse, in a report dated September 14, 1932, states that Miss Hughes is not prepared to undertake tooth brush drill or administer Cod Liver oil to the pupils, nor does she approve of the use of milk in the school.

For the past two years, Corona Readers have been used in all Roman Catholic Indian schools throughout Canada. Father Ryan reported that Miss Hughes had thrown out these readers and introduced the Canadian Readers.

Further, I would draw your attention to paragraph 4 of the report of Dr. W. H. McGill, dated June 16, 1933, to the Honourable the Superintendent General, on his tour of inspection of the Maritime Provinces. One of the schools referred to in Dr. McGill's report is the St. Mary's Indian Day School.

Miss Hughes possesses a second class certificate. Her services are not being dispensed with on the ground that it is intended to install a member of a religious order in her place but was based entirely on the reports of Father Ryan. It is intended, however, if a new teacher is engaged, to obtain the services of one holding a first class certificate.

There are 34 children on the roll at this school, with an average attendance of 24. The Inspector states that, while Miss Hughes does fair work with the lower grades, she fails with the advanced classes. He further states as follows:

"I feel, since Miss Hughes has had this school for nearly 25 years, she could not complain of the Department's out of interest for the Indian, would bring in a new teacher and new life to both the Indian home and school. I do feel she has gone beyond that age in which real active work could be expected for our higher grades."

Acting on Father Ryan's adverse report, the Department considered it necessary, in the interests of the work, to make a change in teacher for the coming school year. Father Ryan has been requested to nominate the services of a teacher having first class qualifications. He has not yet done so and no successor to Miss Hughes has yet been appointed.

No doubt, certain friction has developed between Father Ryan and Miss Hughes. It has been the policy of the Department to rely on reports of inspectors and to base any action taken regarding a change in teacher on such reports.

Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

SIR,

On July 4th I wrote your Department that I had received from
the Reverend F. C. Ryan a notice of dismissal as teacher in the Devon Indian
School, and I asked if this was authorized by the Department but I have not
yet had a reply.

I was unable to understand this notice after 22 years of service,
as my school had always been in good condition, and no complaint had ever
been made against me so far as I know. No person had ever suggested to me
that anything had been wrong with my work and on one occasion the Department
had even presented me with a medal for the excellence of the work done in my
school. I hope, therefore, that you will see not only how unexpected, but
also how unfair and unjust the dismissal proposed by the Reverend F. C. Ryan
would be. I trust that I shall receive word at once that the notice of the
Inspector is cancelled.

I have just heard that the Inspector has made unfavorable reports
against me as a teacher during the last two years. If so, he never made
any representations to me to the effect that my work was not satisfactory,
or that my methods should be changed. When I was teaching in schools which
were inspected by trained inspectors I was complimented for the excellence
of my work.
As I said my school has always been in good condition. I would welcome having my school inspected by any person who knows how to inspect a school; and if I am being dismissed because of the report of Inspector Ryan I would earnestly request that someone who really knows how to inspect a school be sent to do so.

As a matter of fact during two terms during the last two years four of the classes were not examined by the Inspector at all. In the inspections in the Spring of 1931 and 1932 Reverend W. Osborne came to the school with the Inspector and took Grades 1 to IV out of the class room into a small room adjoining and purported to make an examination of them while Father Ryan examined the remaining pupils in the school room. That is all the examination that these grades received. So the inspector would know nothing about their condition except what he was told; and I know nothing about the kind of inspection which they received, because whatever was done was done behind my back.

For sometime I have felt that for some indirect purpose the present Inspector has been trying to get me in an unfavorable position with the Department and I did everything possible to avoid this. I explained this particularly to your representative Mr. Orr when he was here and he assured me that I need not worry about that; but nevertheless I made sure that the Inspector should not have any reasonable cause of complaint against me.

Kindly let me point out a few of the things that have happened during the last few years in connection with this school.
Previous to 1930 the Reverend Father Ryan had expressed himself as greatly pleased with my work because one of my pupils had succeeded in winning a medal for the best essay written in the Indian Schools, and another pupil had succeeded in successfully passing the Normal School Entrance examinations. After this pupil had passed this examination the Normal School authorities refused to accept her as a student; so she went to the Fredericton Business College and obtained a certificate there.

In 1929 the Inspector urged that pupils be prepared for the High School entrance examination. This was really a very difficult matter, as the course of study in the Indian Schools is not fitted to meet the requirements of entrance to high school, and I had to teach the work of the Provincial Schools in addition to the work required by the course in the Indian Schools. I had one pupil who was prepared in this way. I worked very hard with this pupil. I spent a great many hours with her in addition to the regular school hours in giving her instruction, with the result that I succeeded in getting her to the point where she did successfully pass the examination and she received her certificate.

The Inspector had told me that if I succeeded in having this pupil pass this examination successfully it would make a great name for me with the Department. When she did succeed I wrote the Inspector informing him of the fact, expecting he would be greatly pleased with the result; but he never even acknowledged receipt of the letter. Instead, he did this: He wrote the pupil herself that the Department wanted her to go back to my school and qualify to write the entrance examination for the Normal School. In this letter he wrote the following amazing statements:

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6066, file 283-1, part 1)
"Please remember the standing of your teacher is at stake, as well as any further increase in salary, together with the holding of her school, should she be unable to give you the required training,—so you and your parents can rest assured that the teacher is well qualified to do so, and the very moment she is not she does not hold her school."

It is hard to understand what prompted such a letter. Certainly nothing would be more likely to undermine discipline in an Indian School than such a letter about a teacher.

Nevertheless, I was prepared to undertake the work again, but the pupil refused to co-operate. Perhaps one could not expect anything else. Her sister had prepared for and successfully passed a similar examination, which lead to nothing, because the Normal School would not accept her. However I undertook to teach her Geometry and the other necessary subjects not on the ordinary course and did get her over part of the work successfully as the Inspector found when he visited the school—but she would not go on with the work.

Again in 1932 when the Inspector was in the school I showed him some very excellent domestic science work that the pupils had done. Among this was a sweater which a boy of 12 was knitting. The Inspector looked down at the larger boys and stated in a very loud tone:

"It is the wish of the Department that all the large boys make sweaters and if they do not the teacher should resign."

Again it is hard to know what called for such a remark. No doubt he knew that the large boys would not knit sweaters. When I told one of your representatives what the Inspector had done in the presence of the pupils he
stated that in his opinion it was much better for the boys to study the academic work than spend their time in school knitting sweaters.

Then in the fall of 1932 when certain books for use in the school were forwarded to me by the Department the Inspector ordered me not to use them, but to pack them up and send them back. I refused to do that and said I would have to follow the orders of the Superintendent. The Inspector then called out in a loud voice in the presence of the pupils:

"I am the Superintendent. It is my school and if you use any books except those authorized by me, you will be put out."

Apparently from the letter of the Department to me of October 14th last he must have written the Department after this, that I wished to use the Canadian Readers instead of the books which had been sent me. If so, the statement was simply untrue, for I very much preferred those which the Department had sent me and which he ordered me to pack up and send back. I was thus left in a very difficult position and on October 24th, 1932 I had again to write to inquire from the Department whose orders I was to follow—because I then saw that the action of the Inspector was getting me in a place where I might be subject to censure by the Department.

I trust therefore that you will see that justice is done me as a teacher of long standing and that you will not allow me to be thrust aside in this manner.

Yours respectfully,

Memorandum:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

With reference to memoranda of July 27th and August 10th respecting the proposed retirement of Miss Mary T. Hughes, teacher of St. Mary's Indian Day School, North Devon, N.B., I may say that in accordance with your instructions, the services of Miss Hughes are being retained for the ensuing school year.

In this connection I would respectfully point out that Miss Hughes' services are being retained in the face of repeated and emphatic adverse reports on the part of the School Inspector, Rev. F.C. Ryan. This is a situation that can scarcely result otherwise than in a prejudicial effect upon the administration of our educational branch in this agency. I may say that this case is one with which I am personally familiar. I visited this school and met Miss Hughes during my recent visit to New Brunswick, and from even a cursory inspection I gathered a very unfavourable impression of the school and the teacher. This was before I had occasion to read any of Father Ryan's reports.

I fear the effect of Miss Hughes being able to retain her position in the face of the School Inspector's disapproval will not be conducive to discipline, and any improvement in her work can scarcely be expected under the circumstances. Also, the disregard on the part of the Department of our Inspector's advice is likely to have the effect of discouraging this officer from making frank and constructive recommendations in the future. He is not unlikely to be inclined to the opinion that he has not the confidence of the Department, which is not the case.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Fredericton, N.B.
